info.name: Deploy AutoScaling Docker Wordpress Multisite Cluster On AWS

item.name: Deploy High Availability WordPress Multisite
item.description:
In this guide, we are going to create and publish a HA WordPress Multisite cluster.

Caylent Video Tutorial: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=o07ytPajjrU

exec: tests["Access-Control-Allow-Headers equals Origin, X-Requested-With, Content-Type, Accept"]

request.description: If you haven't already, please login.
This step creates a five-node auto scaling cluster.
This request will create a mysql RDS instance for our Wordpress application to use.

Wordpress requires a shared file system. For this, we are going to leverage AWS's Elastic File System (EFS). This simple request notifies our system to attach EFS to all nodes and mount the file system at /mnt/{{EFSUuid}}.
Launch and create the AWS resources for our cluster.

exec: tests['Read Only is boolean and false'] = jsonData.read_only === false;

request.description: Our WordPress Docker service will need to know to use a bind mount. This request creates the bind mount object. Later, we will attach it to the application.
Attach the previously created bind mount to the application.

exec: // Ensure the name of the method matches
tests[`${model} failed to return ${testState} within the alotted time`] = false;
tests[`Not timed out. Timeout at: ${timeoutAt}. Time Now:  ${environment.currentTime}`] = true;

request.description: Check the status of our infrastructure deployment. Repeat this step until stack is fully deployed.
Create the Docker service on the swarm cluster.
List all nodes and endpoints, so you can access the wp-install on a single instance.
